awd_titl_txt: Dehydrogenative Coordination Polymerizations to New         Polymeric Materials
awd_abstract_narration: This award is made in the Office of Special Projects of the                     Chemistry Division and the Division of Materials Research under                 the Materials Synthesis and Processing Initiative.                              Dehydrogenative condensation polymerization of silanes will be                  studied. The research will focus on learning how to control                     polymer growth at the metal center, development of new                          catalysts, and application of the new chemistry to produce                      functionalized polymers with radically new properties. Hybrid                   silicon polymers that contain hydrocarbon unsaturation or                       transition metal centers in the polymer backbone will be made.                  Dehydrogenative coupling will be extended to other metals such                  as stannanes to produce new polymers containing tin-tin bonds.                  %%%                                                                             Polymers containing redox-active metal centers will provide                     access to new conducting polymers, magnetically active                          polymers, macromolecular catalysts or electrode mediator                        systems.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences
